content.title: A 2.0 stay at Hôtel Monville

introduction.small: Immerse yourself in an avant-garde universe amid Montreal's business district at Hôtel Monville, where service is partly carried out by robots.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A 2.0 stay at Hôtel Monville

paragraphs.text:
Only a few strides away from Old Montreal, Hôtel Monville stands out with a 20-storey high futuristic looking building. Pared-down, modern and yet welcoming, the address bets on a new generation concept, mixing ecology and cutting edge technology. There, part of the staff is automated – “until the rise of the machines”, humorously notes the establishment. Robot room service is available 24/7, and electronic check-in allows you to manage your arrival without time constraints. Outsourcing to the automatons also gives human staff a chance to better service you and answer your needs. In an urban, stylish and relaxed environment very much akin to Montreal itself, the location tries to pay tribute to the city of a hundred bell towers. Huge picture windows give way to a natural setting with panoramic views over the region. City lights will lull you to a dreamlike state as the night goes down.

Hôtel Monville
1041, rue de Bleury
Montreal, QC H2Z 1M7

+1 514 379 2000

www.hotelmonville.com/en/

Rooms: from 153 CAD

content.title: Eco-friendly and customisable stay at Boxotel

introduction.small: In Montreal's lively Quartier des spectacles entertainment district, Boxotel is an environmentally-friendly boutique hotel that adapts to the travellers' demands.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Eco-friendly and customisable stay at Boxotel

paragraphs.text:
Along the current eco-friendly modes of tourism, Boxotel is one of those futuristic hotels where everything has been devised to reduce the human pollution to a minimum. The ecological architecture bets on energy efficiency with solar panels on the roof, room arrangements devised to use natural sunlight and an integrated automation system in each room. In addition, the hotel promotes artists, craftsmen and local products: the designer decoration has been conceived by creators from Quebec, and the ground-floor art gallery houses works by various contemporary artists of the region. Each of the twenty housing units is equipped with a kitchen. From studios to lofts with balconies and apartments with private terraces, all spaces are modular. The concept allows you to find the furniture configuration that suits your needs best, so that you will feel right at home.

Boxotel
175, rue Ontario Est
Montreal, QC H2X 1H5

+1 514 281 0202

www.boxotel.com/en/ ﻿

content.title: The 30 poutines of La Banquise

introduction.small: The traditional poutine—fries with melted cheese and an incredible sauce—will make your mouth water at the La Banquise restaurant in Montreal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The 30 poutines of La Banquise

paragraphs.text:
A national dish—rich in calories but oh so appetizing—awaits you at La Banquise, opened in 1968 by Pierre Barsalou. A family business now in the hands of the founder's daughter, Annie Barsalou, La Banquise has acquired a solid reputation over the years, quickly becoming a Montreal institution where locals and tourists mix in a friendly atmosphere.

The poutine, a typical Québécois specialty, appeared on the menu in 1980, with only one version at the time: the ‘Italian poutine'. Now there are no less than 30 different recipes you can choose from, the Taquise—with guacamole, sour cream and tomatoes or the T-Rex for meat eaters, with hamburger, pepperoni, bacon and sausage. There is also the Véganomane with cheese and vegan sauce. For those wanting something else, you can also enjoy burgers, hot dogs and salads, accompanied by exquisite micro-brewery beers.

La Banquise
994, rue Rachel E
Montréal, QC H2J 2J3

+1 514 525 2415

http://labanquise.com/en/

Poutine: from 7.75 CAD

content.title: Discover the Ice Hotel, for a refreshing stay

introduction.small: Like an igloo, this unusual hotel invites you to sleep in one of its 44 refrigerated rooms. An improbable experience that will not leave you cold!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Discover the Ice Hotel, for a refreshing stay

paragraphs.text:
Who said that cold could not be comfortable? Less than three hours from Montreal, you will have the opportunity to spend an enchanting night in a polar setting. Wrapped up in a thick sleeping bag, you will settle into one of the hotel's suites for an unforgettable and unique moment! To sleep, do not forget your hat and gloves as well as your scarf and some long insulating undergarments!

And if the -5° C of your room still gives you some chills, take a moment to relax under the stars in the outdoor sauna. By booking in advance, you can visit the hotel to discover its design, both typical and mysterious. A special package will allow you to enjoy a cocktail in a glass of ice that you will have made yourself! Definitely make the trip!

The Ice Hotel

content.title: A culinary experience in total darkness

introduction.small: O.Noir, the first Canadian restaurant to import the concept of a lunch or dinner in the dark.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A culinary experience in total darkness

paragraphs.text:
The restaurant O.Noir invites you to a table in a particularly dark decor where lamps, candles and even mobile phones are forbidden. Expect your sense of taste to be greatly intensified as foods take on a whole new flavour when you discover them with your eyes closed. Have fun guessing the taste of duck breasts, trout ceviche with tarragon or a mushroom, leek and celery pie.

This experience exacerbates your senses. For O.Noir, it is above all a socially responsible approach where customers and servers (who are blind) are led, during one meal, to 'share' blindness. This original concept was invented by Jorge Spielmann, a blind pastor from Zurich, who used to wrap the eyes of his guests during dinner. In addition, O.Noir donates part of its profits to local associations that help the visually impaired.

O.Noir

content.title: Pullman Wine Bar: dedicated to the pleasures of wine

introduction.small: A stylish bar for those who are considering a good meal accompanied by only the perfect wine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pullman Wine Bar: dedicated to the pleasures of wine

paragraphs.text:
Located in the trendy Plateau district in downtown Montreal, the Pullman Wine Bar, first and foremost, hosts wine lovers and connoisseurs. Unarguably chic, the bar displays its oenological expertise on three floors.

At the entrance, a giant chandelier comprised of 234 wine glasses hangs from the ceiling. The wooden bar, the grey palette, and the jazz music create a 1970s atmosphere. The staff, consisting essentially of sommeliers, guides you in choosing the best nectars.

Changed regularly, the menu is oriented towards tapas such as slightly grilled old cheddar in Port wine, deer tartare and mini bison burgers. With an international wine list and a number of growths served by the glass, the Pullman Wine Bar is also compatible with all budgets.

content.title: W Montreal: chic and upscale elegance

introduction.small: A luxury, ultramodern hotel, just steps from Old Montreal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: W Montreal: chic and upscale elegance

paragraphs.text:
In an old building of the Bank of Canada, W Montreal is a hotel in the forefront of design. Featuring large windows overlooking Victoria Square park, the 150 guestrooms have futuristic lighting, night tables, and phosphorescent rubber ducks in the bathtubs. A solar system of translucent globes suspended under the high lobby ceiling lights contemporary crimson chairs, dark grey sofas, and red cube tables.

At night, you can have dinner at Nom Nom and enjoy their homemade specialities of local inspiration. End the evening at Bartzien, the very 1940s hotel's bar for a delicious Quebec gin tasting.

content.title: A visit to the Canadian Centre for Architecture

introduction.small: A landmark museum that is famous throughout the province of Quebec.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: A visit to the Canadian Centre for Architecture

paragraphs.text:
Founded in 1979, the Canadian Centre for Architecture is located in a beautiful, tastefully restored, 19th-century residence.

Renowned for its educational dimension, the centre hosts a library, bookstore, auditorium, and six rooms for the organisation of exhibitions, public lectures, film screenings, and debates, all aimed at promoting the role of architecture in culture and in society in general. Cross the street that borders the centre to take a walk in the park and discover the sculptures designed by artist/architect Melvin Charney. This is one of the hidden gems of Montreal.

If you are bringing kids along, do not miss the workshops dedicated to the 5-to-18-year-olds. They offer an introduction to the world of architecture and its impact on city life.

Centre canadien d'architecture

content.title: The Leméac: authentic and magical

introduction.small: A bistro with Parisian fashion that serves traditional French cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Leméac: authentic and magical

paragraphs.text:
Located in upscale Outremont and surrounded by shops and trendy restaurants, the Leméac has, in less than 15 years, become one of the pillars of the Montreal food scene.

Try the house specialty: smoked salmon or beef tartar with string fries. Unless you prefer the mushroom ravioli, with pine nuts and arugula, the Candian rack of lamb or stir-fried veal chops in morel sauce. For dessert, the Leméac offers a crême brûlée with Tahitian vanilla and toast with milk jam and maple sugar caramel.

With its elegant decor (tiled floor, mirrored walls, stylish bar stools), its subdued atmosphere, and its menu worthy of the best Parisian bistros, it attracts all of Montreal's gourmets.

Leméac

content.title: Bar Henrietta

introduction.small: A superb neighbourhood bar with Portuguese accents, the Henrietta was designed as a tavern where you can drink well, while tasting very good appetisers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bar Henrietta

paragraphs.text:
Open since December 16, 2015, and located on the former spot of the famous Baldwin Barmacie, the Henrietta was inspired by Portugal and taverns of the 1960s. The place is very welcoming, with a refined loft-style, white brick walls, and industrial spirit.

The space on two floors opens onto a kitchen above and a downstairs bar, and features a solid ceramic wall around the back of the room, lots of wood, and tiny tables. As soon as the warm weather arrives, the micro-terrace at the back is a big draw. You will feel right at home, as though the place had always existed. As for drinks, you will find some classic cocktails executed brilliantly, as well as some home recipes our favourites are the Betty Flanagan and Goldeneye and the Quebec beers. The wine list is comprised of wines imported by Morgane Muszynski.

Though the Henrietta remains primarily a bar, you can also taste a few Portuguese-inspired dishes to share. No doubt you will love this address.

Bar Henrietta

content.title: Mount Royal Park: the green lung of the city

introduction.small: In many ways, Mount Royal is reminiscent of Central Park in Manhattan.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mount Royal Park: the green lung of the city

paragraphs.text:
As he did with its cousin in New York City, Frederick Law Olmsted designed Mount Royal Park, this one between 1873 and 1881.

The highest point of Montreal, and extending over 100 hectares, the park is home to a vast network of walking paths and stairs, a body of water (Beaver Lake), wooded hills, secret paths, esplanades, gently or steeply sloping lawns, and habitats for hundreds of birds and other wildlife. The beautiful lookouts and the impressive Saint Joseph's Oratory whose 38-metre-in-diameter copper dome rises to 97 metres high offer impressive views of Montreal and the surrounding region.

Run, row, skate, toboggan, read, walk, dream, stroll, flirt, listen to the famous tom-toms and dance, or picnic in the summer as a family. In short, a true paradise.

Mount Royal

content.title: Hotel Saint-Paul: award-winning design

introduction.small: A hotel situated in a magnificent historic building in Old Montreal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Saint-Paul: award-winning design

paragraphs.text:
As one of the very first design hotels to have been built in Canada, the Saint-Paul features a richly detailed Beaux-Arts facade that conceals ten purely contemporary floors. Inspired by nature, the decoration of the 120 rooms and suites alternates, depending on the floor, between the themes of fire, air, water and earth.

Expect monochromatic red bands and touches of orange and brown in the 'earth' rooms. The 'sky' rooms feature serene and monochrome expanses of white, cream and grey-blue. The suede headboards, the faux fur rugs and chairs in cowhide prints, contrast with the dark wooden floors and pale walls. The windows provide natural light and privileged views of the city and the old port.

Hambar, the hotel's restaurant, serves market cuisine and fine deli dishes, including gourmet ham.

Hôtel Saint-Paul

content.title: Liverpool House: the charm of a seaside cottage

introduction.small: A super-trendy Italian restaurant hidden in the animated quarter of Little Burgundy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Liverpool House: the charm of a seaside cottage

paragraphs.text:
As well-known as Joe Beef, its big brother next door, the Liverpool House is an institution, both casual and terribly trendy, that specialises in Italian cuisine.

Enjoy generous dishes such as lobster spaghetti, quail served with an inventive mix of chicory and rhubarb or large dish to share, the huge prime rib of beef à la bordelaise for instance, perfect for two. For dessert, try the pecan whipped cream.

With its wooden tables, contemporary art works, and creative menus that change each week, the Liverpool House welcomes you in a warm atmosphere prized by Montreal's socialites. Reservations recommended.

content.title: Auberge du Vieux-Port: the quintessential Montreal

introduction.small: The rustic charm of a historic building on the riverfront.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Auberge du Vieux-Port: the quintessential Montreal

paragraphs.text:
Located in a former factory building from 1882, the Auberge du Vieux-Port welcomes you into a rustic atmosphere with friendly service and all the latest technologies.

Not only the original stone walls, massive beams, and romantic brass beds, but also the elegant furnishings of the 45 rooms will delight you. The tall French windows overlook the St. Lawrence River and the old rue Saint-Paul. Modernity is represented by big-screen TVs, free Wi-Fi, and hot tubs.

For views of the Old Port, head to the roof terrace where meals are served from May to September. The rustic atmosphere extends into the Taverne Gaspar, which offers English pub food with Franco-Quebecois influences. In another building behind the hotel, 24 apartments are available for longer stays.

content.title: Bota Bota: an innovative floating spa

introduction.small: Docked at St. Lawrence Quai in the heart of Old Montreal, Bota Bota is a floating universe of relaxation and well-being.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bota Bota: an innovative floating spa

paragraphs.text:
Formerly a traversiere (which is what Quebecers call a ferry) and theatre-boat, this boat-spa includes five decks over which are spread all the infrastructures and spa facilities: steam bath, Jacuzzis, two saunas with views of the river and Old Montreal, showers and cold baths, relaxation areas and lounges, terraces and garden and outdoor pools with 30°C water. A moment of wellness i the midst of the frenzy of the city.

Note that there are supplements, including a large choice of treatments and massages, as well as yoga and Pilates classes, unless you prefer simply a good manicure. You need only remember to bring your own flip-flops or slippers, as the establishment does not loan these.

Bota Bota
Vieux-Port

content.title: Old Port of Montreal skating rink

introduction.small: The most beautiful rink overlooking Montreal is the ideal place to practice ice-skating, the national pastime.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Port of Montreal skating rink

paragraphs.text:
Glide about on the most beautiful outdoor skating rink in Montreal. The site is enchanting and, especially on weekends, one of the most popular spots for local families.

Welcoming both big and small, the ice rink, located in the heart of Old Montreal on the Old Port, offers an incomparable view of the city. On one side you have the view of the buildings of Montreal's heritage and, on the other, the beautiful sight of the snow-covered river, a visual souvenir that will be long remembered. You can rent your skates on site and there are also cafés for a hot drink, a snack, or a fine meal.

Note there are theme evenings on Tuesdays, Wednesdays, and Thursdays, during which the magic of skating is enhanced by the nocturnal ambiance and music.

Vieux-Port ice-skating rink

content.title: The ‘Village': Montreal's gay quarter

introduction.small: More than a village, a world. Discover the experience of a vibrantly original neighbourhood that is open and welcoming.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The ‘Village': Montreal's gay quarter

paragraphs.text:
Venturing into Montreal's gay district, otherwise known as the 'Village', is a must. It is nothing less than the largest gay neighbourhood in ​​the world and surely one of the most festive and most famous.

A globally recognised destination, visiting is a full-on experience. Every year it hosts thousands of tourists from countries all over the world many of them LGBT or gay-friendly, of course, but not exclusively so. It is full of life and vitality, with nearly 60 restaurants, terraces, and bars. Its main street is pedestrianized in summer, making the tour of the neighbourhood, day and night, particularly pleasant.

Between the Beaudry and Papineau metro stations, thousands of hanging garlands and pink balls transform the street into an urban art gallery, marking the busiest part of the Village, where concerts, events, and festivals are held. Totally unique!

content.title: Hotel Gault: loft style

introduction.small: Spacious rooms in a former carpet factory.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Gault: loft style

paragraphs.text:
Behind a stone facade in the historic district of Old Montreal, this 1870 building, an old fabric warehouse, conceals a hotel with industrial decor and contemporary furnishings. Arched windows and cast-iron columns surround the hall on the concrete floor, strewn with chairs and tables designed by Bertoia Bird.

Each of the 30 rooms, which are all different from one another, reveals a magnificent panorama of the city and each contains angular furniture in oak and bare brick walls. Designer bathrooms with egg-shaped tubs are the ultimate comfort elements dear to North American luxury hotels. Ochre sheets and comforters cover the more than comfortably sized beds. In this minimalist sanctuary, the gym and room service are open at all hours.

Have a massage in your room and lunch on a daily market special at the restaurant Gault.

Hôtel Gault

content.title: Saint-Denis Theatre: in the heart of the Latin Quarter

introduction.small: Part of the city's history for nearly a century, the Saint-Denis Theatre is ‘the' theatre in Montreal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Denis Theatre: in the heart of the Latin Quarter

paragraphs.text:
St. Denis Theatre opened March 4, 1916 and since then has been a major monument in the cultural space of the metropolis.

Throughout the 20th century, the New York Metropolitan Opera, the Bolshoi Ballet, the Comédie Francaise and Stravinksy have performed there, as did the biggest French and international stars, who in turn presented their music-hall shows: Gilbert Bécaud, Maurice Chevalier, Fernandel, Luis Mariano, Yves Montand, Tino Rossi... Located in the heart of the Latin Quarter, this entertainment landmark includes two large theatres (one with 2,218 seats and another with 933), with performances year round from all sources and all genres: humour (the famous 'Just for Laughs Festival' is held each year within its walls), songs, musicals (in the spring of 2016, Grease took centre stage for eight exceptional performances), theatre, etc.
The Saint-Denis Theatre remains a must for big names in show business.

Théâtre Saint-Denis

content.title: Hotel Nelligan: urban and refined

introduction.small: All the charm of European hotels, and all the comfort and intelligent luxury of North America, can be found in these modern, cosy rooms near the Old Port.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Nelligan: urban and refined

paragraphs.text:
The soul of the Quebec poet Émile Nelligan inhabits this boutique hotel in Old Montreal. His poems are framed in the 105 rooms and suites of these three renovated warehouses that date from the 19th century.

The rooms are modern and cosy with their brick walls, their dark wood furniture, and their gas fireplaces. Continental breakfast and tea in the afternoon are served in the four-floor atrium, with garden and fountain. The roof terrace, open only in summer, offers light meals and beautiful vistas.

The hotel restaurant, Verses, features modern French cuisine and one of the best views over Old Montreal. A bar/brasserie called the Méchant Boeuf is open until 3:00 a.m., serving burgers, steaks, and seafood.

content.title: Pointe-à-Caillère: the Montreal Museum of Archaeology and History

introduction.small: To learn everything about the history of the city of Montreal, visit the Pointe-à-Caillère Museum.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pointe-à-Caillère: the Montreal Museum of Archaeology and History

paragraphs.text:
This museum is located in Fort Ville-Marie, on a point of land between the St. Lawrence River and Petite Riviere. Paul Chomedey, Sieur de Maisonneuve, and Jeanne Mance inaugurated it in 1992 on the occasion of the festivities marking the 350th anniversary of the founding of the city.

Discover the history of Montreal, its changes and development from the period of the indigenous peoples until today, via the French and British influences and even the emergence of cinema in Quebec. The introduction to the visit begins in the form of a multimedia and digital spectacle. Do not miss the opportunity to go down to the archaeological site to better understand the fascinating past of the city.

Also note that new areas have been developed and inaugurated for the celebration of the 375th anniversary of the city in 2017.

Pointe-à-Caillère

Montréal, QC H2Y 3Y5

content.title: Bouillon Bilk: a simple but quality place

introduction.small: A kitchen that stands out for its research while remaining accessible to all budgets.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bouillon Bilk: a simple but quality place

paragraphs.text:
With a modest address in Montreal's city centre, Bouillon Bilk reveals a simple but tasty menu with artistically presented dishes.

The chef François Nadon presents seven starters, six main dishes, and a handful of desserts, with attention to the richness of flavours. The dishes include lobster with beans, olives and tomatoes or a shrimp, carrot and basil risotto. The house specialty is a lamb, salsa verde, raisins, cauliflower and semolina preparation.

The wine list features many wines available by the glass. Finish with a platter of cheese from Quebec or mini-pastries. Equipped with a bar and rustic wooden tables, Bouillon Bilk welcomes Montreal gourmets in a subdued atmosphere.

Bouillon Bilk

content.title: Place d'Armes Hotel: a treasure house of traditions

introduction.small: Sophisticated accommodation in an architectural wonder, in front of the Notre-Dame Basilica.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Place d'Armes Hotel: a treasure house of traditions

paragraphs.text:
Located in three 19th-century neoclassical buildings, the Place d'Armes Hotel offers 169 rooms and suites of rare elegance. High ceilings, wood panelling, large arched windows, and bare brick blend harmoniously with modern amenities like electric fireplaces, the atmosphere of the place, the walk-in showers, and latest generation Jacuzzis.

Kyo, the hotel's restaurant, offers Japanese flavours in an izakaya style, while Suite 701, which is more sophisticated, serves free breakfast and bistro-like dishes in a modern ambiance from the end the afternoon, is the place for trendy after-work meet-ups. If you want a little time to relax, go to the third floor 'Rainspa', with its cerulean-blue tile, for the hammam, the first built in Montreal.

In warm weather, head to the terrace to join members of the jet set on white leather sofas and enjoy your cocktails with views of Notre-Dame Basilica, Mount Royal, and the nearby historic district.

content.title: Joe Beef

introduction.small: The rallying point for meat lovers in the heart of Little Burgundy, close to the Atwater market.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Joe Beef

paragraphs.text:
A tribute to Charles 'Joe Beef' McKiernan, a 19th-century working-class hero, the restaurant, hidden in vibrant Little Burgundy, remains at the forefront of trends.

Appreciated by gourmets and the city's top chefs, this casual bistro offers a revisited French cuisine menu that is renewed daily. Start your meal with a half-dozen oysters or foie gras en croûte (in a crust) with a spiral of Quebec honey. Continue with a succulent steak served with thick chips. Try the house specialties: spaghetti with lobster and char-grilled shoulder of lamb.

Dine in the garden, surrounded by some of the vegetables and herbs used in the dishes on the menu. The atmosphere is light, with dim lights, rustic tables, and a slate displaying the wines. Not to be missed.

introduction.small: Extensive warm spaces with elegant finishes.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Saint-Sulpice: in the shadow of the basilica

paragraphs.text:
There are no half-measure at the Saint-Sulpice, a four-star establishment located in the district of Old Montreal, in the shadow of the Notre-Dame Basilica. The 108 rooms and suites are between 50 and 140 square metres in size and accept up to four people in a beautiful decor that includes dark wood furniture, soft leather, and a neutral palette.

In summer, French windows open onto a sunny terrace, in the middle of the gardens. Flat-screen TVs with children's channels and free Wi-Fi connect you to the world. In the Deluxe and Executive suites, enjoy a balcony or a fireplace, depending on the season.

You can prepare meals in the kitchenette, or head down to Sinclair, which serves delicious French cuisine in a chic and subtly lit decor.

content.title: Algonquin Provincial Park: a tour that is worth the journey

introduction.small: A 5-hour drive west of Montreal, Algonquin Provincial Park is a must-see destination for the beauty and richness of Canada's flora and fauna.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Algonquin Provincial Park: a tour that is worth the journey

paragraphs.text:
The activities offered by Algonquin Provincial Park include hiking, mountain biking, canoeing and horseback riding, cross country skiing, and fishing. The park spans an area of more than 7,600 square kilometres between Georgian Bay on Lake Huron and the Ottawa River.

Among the points of interest that should not be missed, are the Opeongo, Canoe, and Smoke lakes, which are among the most popular of the 2,400 lakes and 1,200 kms of waterways in the park. The bright and bubbling waters of the Petawawa River will appeal to those who are fond of rafting and its accompanying thrills. The isolated shores of Lake Nipissing, meanwhile, are perfect if you like fishing.

There is also, within the park, a visitor centre, a grocery store, a snack bar, a gas station, and mini-rental shops for equipment.

content.title: Old Montreal: a must

introduction.small: A real journey in time, this is where you fall in love with the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Old Montreal: a must

paragraphs.text:
Built close to the St. Lawrence River and stretching from the streets of the Commune (south), Saint-Antoine (north), McGill (west), and Berri Street (east), Old Montreal is a pedestrian area par excellence.

It is a wonderful opportunity to stroll cobbled alleys blending the modern with the old, recent buildings with period buildings boasting noble stone facades. On the Place d'Armes, a visit to the Notre-Dame Basilica is well worth the time. This basilica, a precious religious heritage of Quebec, has no equivalent in the province and fascinates with its rich interior ornaments. Go through the Bonsecours Market, the old public market, which today has become the seat of the Quebec Craft Council, and head towards the Place Jacques-Cartier, one of the most beautiful, if not the most beautiful, of town squares.

Wholly pedestrian since 1998, it's a great place for a break in one of the many restaurants and cafés housed in the imposing historic homes. The floral displays add additional colour to this picturesque tourist attraction.

content.title: Latin Quarter: bohemian rhapsody

introduction.small: Boutiques, trendy cafés, a bohemian atmosphere, and an artist population: Welcome to the Latin Quarter.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Latin Quarter: bohemian rhapsody

paragraphs.text:
Montreal's Latin Quarter is located in the immediate vicinity of Ville-Marie. Like its big brother in Paris, it mainly hosts artists, intellectuals, and now also students.

The Francophone university UQAM (University of Quebec at Montreal), with a distinguished international reputation, brings together 41,000 students installed in the most beautiful buildings in the city the cathedral serves, for example, as entry to certain classrooms. Meanwhile, in the heart of the Latin Quarter, the entertainment district hosts more than 30 theatres and an engaging range of art galleries.

The Latin Quarter loves authors, musicians and artists of all kinds. Stroll through the always-bustling Rue Saint-Denis, with its sidewalk cafés, bookshops, restaurants, and countless bars. This is a must during your stay in Montreal.

content.title: The Montreal Canadiens at the Bell Centre

introduction.small: To attend an ice hockey game, go to the Bell Centre, the residence of the ‘Habs'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Montreal Canadiens at the Bell Centre

paragraphs.text:
Since its inauguration in 1996, then under the name of the Molson Centre, the Bell Centre has been a main stage for the presentation of sports, arts, and culture in Montreal.

Home of the 'Habs', the Anglophone nickname for the Montreal Canadiens hockey club, the Bell Centre offers all the state-of-the-art technology needed to ensure a perfect atmosphere. The lair of the legendary local hockey team, the most successful in the history of the NHL, the North American professional league, with 24 Stanley Cups, attracts over 1 million visitors each year. These skaters in their red jerseys perform before sold-out audiences in this highly charged amphitheatre that holds 21,273 spectators. Seats are hard to get, so we advise you to book in advance, even if a quota is always on sale on the day of the game.

Like many popular sporting events, the atmosphere can be over-excited, with the audience shouting, singing, urging on, and exulting to the sound of 'Go, Habs, Go!' What would a visit to Montreal be without a hockey game?

Bell Centre

content.title: Montreal Botanical Garden: for nature lovers

introduction.small: A Montreal flagship, recognized as one of the largest botanical gardens in the world.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Montreal Botanical Garden: for nature lovers

paragraphs.text:
The Montreal Botanical Garden offers highly colourful all-season programming featuring events, exhibitions, and conferences. Opened June 9, 1931 by Brother Marie-Victorin and architect Henry Teuscher, it covers nearly 75 hectares.

With its collection of 22,000 plant species and cultivars, ten exhibition greenhouses, the Frédéric-Back House of Trees and 20 themed gardens, such as the Chinese garden, the rose garden, and the undergrowth garden, it is also the perfect place to stock up on fresh air. Located just minutes from downtown Montreal, near the Biodome and the Olympic Park, the Montreal Botanical Garden includes plants from around the globe.

While waiting for the Insectarium and the Biodome – undergoing renovation – to reopen, pay a visit to the Rio Tinto Alcan Planetarium, inaugurated in 1966 and totally modernised in 2013. It boasts an innovative approach in terms of architecture, technology and visitor experience. At the Rio Tinto Alcan Planetarium, you will bend the limits of both time and space.

Montreal Botanical Garden

content.title: Museum of Fine Arts: from Cézanne to Inuit Art

introduction.small: An internationally renowned museum dedicated to the promotion of Canadian and international art.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Museum of Fine Arts: from Cézanne to Inuit Art

paragraphs.text:
Combining both a rich cultural history and a thriving arts scene, Montreal is home to the most important museums and art galleries in the country, including the Museum of Fine Arts, the oldest and most prestigious of Canadian art institutions.

Founded in 1860 and installed in its current building since 1912, the museum is accessible on either side of Sherbrooke Street and is spread over a series of four neighbouring houses, connected by an underground tunnel. Visit the Desmarais Pavilion, famous for its international art collection, including works by Cézanne, Picasso, Monet, Rembrandt, Rodin, Matisse, and Kandinsky. The underground gallery offers art collections of the world Islamic art and art from Africa, Asia, and Oceania. Then head to the Michal and Renata Hornstein Pavilion to explore world cultures, Mediterranean archaeology, and ethnic art.

Finally, head to the Claire and Marc Bourgie Pavilion to discover the best of the Quebec and Canadian art scene, as well as antique Tiffany stained glass and a collection of Inuit art.

content.title: Surfing in Montreal: indoors or on the St. Lawrence...

introduction.small: Come tame the waves, because surfing in Montreal is, of course, possible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Surfing in Montreal: indoors or on the St. Lawrence...

paragraphs.text:
No need for Tofino, Honolulu, or Bali to go surfing. Montreal is known by insiders for its beautiful river waves in summer, right beside the Old Port.

Unlike ocean waves, river waves are not dynamic but stationary, so they remain on site. Surfing in Montreal therefore has a very significant advantage. Rather than wait for the perfect wave to come to you, it is waiting for you to come at it! For surf bums who want to surf all seasons, Maeva Surf is the indoor surfing centre with the most dynamic, the safest, and most popular waves in the world since 2010.

For a free session if you are experienced, a group class, a private or semi-private course, testing the flowboard is a unique experience, available only in Canada.

Maeva Surf

content.title: Le Petit Hotel: near Montreal's most beautiful sites

introduction.small: A fashionable and intimate hotel in the old quarter that embodies the essence of the city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Petit Hotel: near Montreal's most beautiful sites

paragraphs.text:
The Saint-Sulpice does not pull punches. This four-star establishment is located in the district of Old Montreal, in the shadow of the Notre-Dame Basilica. The 108 rooms and suites are between 50 and 140 square metres in size and accept up to four people in a beautiful decor that includes dark wood furniture, soft leather, and a neutral palette.

In summer, French windows open onto a sunny terrace, in the middle of the gardens. Flat-screen TVs with children's channels and free Wi-Fi connect you to the world. In the Deluxe and Executive suites, enjoy a balcony or a fireplace, depending on the season.

You can prepare meals in the kitchenette, or head down to Sinclair, which serves delicious French cuisine in a chic and subtly lit decor.

content.title: The Lab Bar: on an international level

introduction.small: A sophisticated cocktail bar with an experienced team of mixologists.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Lab Bar: on an international level

paragraphs.text:
On the edge of Parc La Fontaine, the Lab is the absolute reference in terms of cocktail bars in Montreal. Trained in Paris, the co-owner and manager Fabien Maillard brings all his talent to this super-trendy establishment.

Enter the Lab universe: its doors are draped in red fake fur, the walls are bare brick, the tables are high, and its bar is filled with rare and classic ingredients. Every six months, Fabien and his "labtenders" create a new menu from inventive flavours. Watch them juggle bottles and spit fire with their creations. Taste the Mirliflore, with bitters, ginger syrup, lemon, carrot and gin. Relax in the intimate atmosphere to the sound of cool jazz. A must address.

content.title: Le Filet: chic marine atmosphere

introduction.small: A racy meal, slightly Japanese in style, celebrating seafood.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Filet: chic marine atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
Two famous Montreal restaurateurs, Hubert Marsolais and Claude Pelletier, are behind Le Filet, a discreet address on bustling Mont Royal Avenue, to whose cooking the chef Yasu Okazaki brings an Asian touch.

Each dish is served with meticulous precision. Enjoy a tuna tartare, poached egg and nori, or the wagyu tataki with eggplant and miso. These delicious dishes, built to be shared, are accompanied by wonderful wines available from a list that has been developed with science and talent.

With its stylish decor wooden tables and dark red chairs contrast with walls of brass and galvanized steel Le Filet exudes a warm and relaxed atmosphere that has charmed a growing customer base.

content.title: Jean-Talon Market: Montreal's best

introduction.small: Montreal has a wide variety of markets, both covered and open air. Gourmets will find the ingredients to cook the local specialty, ‘poutine'.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Jean-Talon Market: Montreal's best

paragraphs.text:
It the heart of the city, in the Little Italy neighbourhood, which, as you can imagine, is characterised by its large Italian community, stands the most attractive market in the city, the very authentic Jean-Talon Market named after the first intendant of New France in the 17th century.

This ‘market of flavours' offers, seven days a week, fish, vegetables, baked breads, and even kitchenware. Take advantage of the food served directly at the stands and prepared by the surrounding bistros: wild salmon, smoked sturgeon, organic sausages, smoked duck with maple wood, or caribou soup. Ask the merchants, who will be glad to explain the best combinations and ways to consume their produce. Obviously, you will learn everything you ever wanted to know about maple syrup (and more) and its myriad uses in the kitchen.

As for drinks, try the craft beers, the wines of Quebec, and the local cider. To get there, take the metro to the Jean-Talon station and follow the empty shopping bags.

content.title: Notre-Dame Basilica: no equivalent in Montreal

introduction.small: The most important monument of Old Montreal and one of Quebec's most precious religious heritages.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Notre-Dame Basilica: no equivalent in Montreal

paragraphs.text:
Designed by the Irish architect James O'Donnell and built between 1824 and 1829, this colossal Gothic basilica contains a superb medieval-style interior with walnut wood carvings, detailed stained glass, 24k gold stars on a vaulted blue ceiling, as well as the largest Casavant Brothers organ (with 5,572 tubes) in North America.

Do not miss the paintings in the nave and the impressive Chapel of Our Lady of the Sacred Heart (or ‘wedding chapel') behind the altar. The largest church in Montreal is also the most valuable building of Quebec's architectural heritage. It is a veritable religious art gallery, and the richness of its interior ornaments has no equivalent in the city.

Note that the entrance of Notre Dame is not free, but it is one of the most visited of the city's attractions. We suggest you arrive early to avoid the large tourist busses.

content.title: Montreal Museum of Contemporary Art: the art of today

introduction.small: More than 7,000 works, including paintings, films, and photographs are collected here.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Montreal Museum of Contemporary Art: the art of today

paragraphs.text:
Located on the Place des Arts and an integral part of its complex, the Museum of Contemporary Art (MAC) is at the heart of a culturally vibrant quarter. Inaugurated in 1964, the museum hosts contemporary art in the most general sense, in a style that is decidedly 'design'.

This ultramodern enclosure is the only one in the country to be dedicated exclusively to the art of today, featuring the full range of the contemporary art scene. While the museum is focused on Quebec and Canadian art, it is also open to the most iconic international artists.

Besides the permanent exhibition of more than7,000 works including paintings, films, and photographs, do not forget to visit the MAC for its temporary exhibitions: dance, experimental theatre, live music... Nocturnal openings are organised every Friday, with a DJ, live performances, and a bar for 'a night at the museum'.

content.title: Verses Sky-Baron the terrace of the Nelligan Hotel

introduction.small: An open-sky bar with panoramic views of Old Montreal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Verses Sky-Baron the terrace of the Nelligan Hotel

paragraphs.text:
Located in the heart of Old Montreal, Verses Sky-Bar in the Hotel Nelligan (named after Émile Nelligan, the famous Quebec author) has exceptional views of the river and the city. On the fifth floor, this outdoor bar is furnished with high stools and rustic wooden tables. Start the evening with the house specialty, sangria mixed with sparkling white wine and lychees, or opt for a Nelligan Martini, a mix of rum, raspberry liquor, and grapefruit juice. During the summer months, the Verses fire pits grill to serve meat of the finest quality, as well as fresh fish. Enjoy the view onto the St. Lawrence and Notre-Dame, and savour grilled salmon with chutney or pork ribs with blueberries. Praised by celebrities, the place is also popular with Montrealers leaving their offices at the end of the day.
